description: From Middle English delicious, from Anglo-Norman delicious, from Old French delicious, delicieux, from Late Latin dēliciōsus (“delicate, delicious”), from dēliciae (“delights”), plural of dēlicia (“pleasure”), from deliciō (“I allure, I entice”), from de- (“away”) + laciō (“I lure, I deceive”), from Proto-Italic *lakjō (“to draw, pull”), of unknown ultimate origin. Displaced native Middle English ēstful, from Old English ēstful.

adjectives.description: delicious (comparative more delicious, superlative most delicious)

entries.meaning: Pleasing to the sense of taste; tasty.
(colloquial, figurative) Pleasing to a person's taste; pleasing to the eyes or mind.
